verses.transliteration: divyamālyāmbaradharaṃ divyagandhānulepanaṃ | sarvāścaryamayaṃ devam anantaṃ viśvatomukham ||
verses.translation: Wearing divine garlands and garments, anointed with divine fragrances — all-wonderful, divine, infinite, with faces everywhere.

commentary.dadaji: Sanjaya continues his description for the blind king Dhritarashtra, painting the cosmic form in its glorious aspect — divine garlands, divine fragrances, all-wonderful. The word 'viśvatomukha' — facing all directions — is perhaps the most important detail: God has no 'back.' There is no angle from which His face is not turned toward you. No matter where you stand, no matter what you have done or left undone, the cosmic face of the Divine is looking at you with the same infinite gaze. This is the ultimate reassurance of the Gita.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The description of the cosmic form as wearing divine ornaments reflects the Vedic understanding that the cosmos is not barren matter but is itself the self-expression of divine consciousness — decorated, vibrant, meaningful. The Taittiriya Upanishad speaks of 'ānandamaya' — the universe as bliss-made — and this verse touches that same truth. 'Viśvatomukha' — facing all directions — is a direct echo of the Isha Upanishad: 'Sa paryagāt' — 'He pervades in all directions.' The infinite faces of the cosmic form represent the omnidirectional awareness of Brahman, from which nothing is hidden or absent.
commentary.yogananda: In deep meditation, the cosmic form reveals itself as light — infinite, blazing, fragrant with spiritual joy. The divine garlands and fragrances are not imaginative embellishments but direct reports of subtle-plane perception: the higher planes of existence are genuinely more beautiful, more vibrant, more filled with divine qualities than what the physical senses can apprehend. 'Anantam viśvatomukham' — infinite, facing everywhere — describes the AUM: the primordial sound that pervades all space equally, from which all creation emanates in every direction simultaneously.
commentary.goyandka: Sanjaya's description of the cosmic form combines the majestic (divyamālya, divyagandhānulepana — divine garlands and fragrances) with the overwhelming (anantam viśvatomukha — infinite, omnidirectional). This dual nature reflects the dual response of the devotee before the Viśvarūpa: aesthetic delight in its beauty and existential awe at its infinity. The Purāṇas describe the viśvatomukha aspect as the Viśvarūpa's most characteristic feature — even the Vedic sacrificial post (yūpa) is called viśvatomukha because it symbolises the omnipresence of the sacrifice's ultimate recipient: Brahman Himself.

verses.sanskrit: दिवि सूर्यसहस्रस्य भवेद्युगपदुत्थिता | यदि भाः सदृशी सा स्याद्भासस्तस्य महात्मनः ||
verses.transliteration: divi sūryasahasrasya bhavet yugapad utthitā | yadi bhāḥ sadṛśī sā syād bhāsas tasya mahātmanaḥ ||
verses.translation: If the radiance of a thousand suns were to blaze forth simultaneously in the sky — that might resemble the splendour of that great-souled One.

commentary.dadaji: This is one of the most famous verses of the entire Gita — J. Robert Oppenheimer, witnessing the world's first nuclear test at Trinity in 1945, recalled this verse: 'Now I am become Death, the destroyer of worlds.' The verse tells us that if a thousand suns blazed simultaneously, that is only perhaps what the radiance of the Lord might resemble — and even this is a simile, an approximation that falls infinitely short. What does this mean for us? It means that every moment we are in the presence of something whose splendour exceeds all possible human measurement. Yet this same infinite radiance knows your name, holds your hand, loves you.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The 'thousand suns' simile is the Vedic tradition's way of pointing toward the ineffable — the Kena Upanishad declares 'yad manasā na manute' — 'that which the mind cannot think' — and Sanjaya reaches for the largest possible image and then hedges it with 'sadṛśī sā syāt' — 'it might be similar.' The language of approximation is crucial: the conditional mood (bhavet, syāt) signals that even this cosmic image is acknowledged as inadequate. Brahman's light is self-luminous (svayamprakāśa) — it is the very precondition of all other light; a thousand suns are themselves illumined by It, not the other way around.
commentary.yogananda: In the highest states of samadhi, the meditator experiences light — an inner light more brilliant than the outer sun, yet perfectly peaceful and not blinding. This is the light that Arjuna is perceiving through the divine eye (divya cakṣu) that Krishna gave him. Paramahansa Yogananda wrote: 'When the spiritual eye opens, you behold the divine light as billions of suns.' The thousand-sun image is Sanjaya's honest attempt to describe something that transcends all physical analogy — and even his most extreme comparison falls short. Every atom of that light is conscious, blissful, and permeated with love.
commentary.goyandka: This verse (11.12) stands as one of the great poetic achievements of the Mahābhārata — the comparison of the Viśvarūpa's splendour to a thousand simultaneous suns is the most powerful cosmic image in all of Sanskrit literature. Sanjaya's grammar is carefully hedged: 'sā syāt' — 'it would be (merely similar)' — indicating that even this image cannot capture the full reality. The traditional commentators note that this verse should be read alongside the Puruṣa Sūkta: 'ādityavarṇaṃ tamasaḥ parastāt' — 'Beyond darkness, of the colour of the sun' — both texts pointing to the same self-luminous Brahman that transcends all created luminosity. This is the verse to contemplate in moments of prayer: that the Being to whom you pray is more brilliant than ten billion suns, yet more intimate than your own heartbeat.

verses.sanskrit: तत्रैकस्थं जगत्कृत्स्नं प्रविभक्तमनेकधा | अपश्यद्देवदेवस्य शरीरे पाण्डवस्तदा ||
verses.transliteration: tatraikasthaṃ jagat kṛtsnaṃ pravibhaktam anekadhā | apaśyad devadevasya śarīre pāṇḍavas tadā ||
verses.translation: Then the Pandava (Arjuna) saw the entire universe — divided in many ways — standing in one place in the body of the God of gods.

commentary.dadaji: This is the pinnacle of spiritual vision — seeing the entire universe in one place, in God's body. Not the universe as chaotic fragments scattered across space and time, but the universe as a unified whole, 'divided in many ways' yet fundamentally one. This is what the saints and sages experience in their deepest states: unity in the midst of multiplicity, God's body as the very substance of all that exists. You and I and the stars and the rivers are all parts of this same one body. What would it do to our relationships, our conflicts, our wars, if we genuinely saw this?
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse is the experiential confirmation of the Vedantic mahāvākya 'sarvam khalv idam brahma' — all this is indeed Brahman. The Chandogya Upanishad teaches this as a verbal proposition; Chapter 11 of the Gita presents it as Arjuna's actual visual experience. 'Ekastham jagat kṛtsnam pravibhaktam anekadhā' — the universe as one (ekastha) yet diversified (pravibhakta anekadhā) — is the precise description of the Vedantic paradox: Brahman is one, undivided, yet the apparent multiplicity of the world arises from and within that one. The divine eye sees both the unity and the diversity without contradiction.
commentary.yogananda: The great mystics of all traditions have described this moment — the cosmic vision where the illusion of separation dissolves and the whole universe is seen as one living being. Meister Eckhart saw 'all things in God'; the Sufi poet Rumi wrote of the drop realising it is the ocean. Arjuna's experience here is the direct perceptual realisation of what the entire Gita has been teaching in words. 'Ekastham' — in one place — is the key: not distributed across space, but all simultaneously present in the eternal Now. This is what samadhi reveals: the spatial separation of the world is itself a kind of optical illusion of the individuated mind.
commentary.goyandka: Sanjaya's description reaches its summit in this verse — the entire universe (jagat kṛtsnam), though appearing differentiated in countless ways (pravibhaktam anekadhā), is seen as one (ekastham) in the body of the Supreme Lord. This is the vivid resolution of the philosophical question that the Gita poses from Chapter 1: what is the relationship between the individual, the world, and the Supreme? Here the answer is given visually: the world and all its contents are within the Lord, held in and by Him. Traditional commentators cite this verse to establish the Viśiṣṭādvaita teaching of sarvam viṣṇumayam — all is pervaded by Vishnu; the Advaita reads it as 'sarvam brahma' — all is the one undivided Brahman.

verses.sanskrit: ततः स विस्मयाविष्टो हृष्टरोमा धनञ्जयः | प्रणम्य शिरसा देवं कृताञ्जलिरभाषत ||
verses.transliteration: tataḥ sa vismayāviṣṭo hṛṣṭaromā dhanañjayaḥ | praṇamya śirasā devaṃ kṛtāñjalir abhāṣata ||
verses.translation: Then Dhananjaya (Arjuna), overwhelmed with amazement, with hair standing on end, bowed his head to the Lord and, with palms joined, spoke.

word_breakdown.meaning: with hair standing on end (goosebumps of awe)

commentary.dadaji: Before words, there is the body's response — hair standing on end, palms pressed together, head bowed. This is what genuine contact with the Divine does to a human being: it bypasses the rational mind and goes straight to the nervous system, straight to the heart. 'Hṛṣṭaromā' — the hair standing on end in awe — is the same response described in South Indian classical aesthetics as the highest aesthetic emotion, 'romāñca,' the sign that something transcendent has touched the human soul. Then Arjuna collects himself and speaks. Everything in this verse — the awe, the prostration, the joined palms — is a model for our own approach to prayer.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Sanjaya's description of Arjuna's physical state before he speaks — vismayāviṣṭa (overcome with wonder), hṛṣṭaromā (hair standing on end), praṇamya śirasā (bowed with his head), kṛtāñjaliḥ (palms joined) — encodes the complete posture of the ideal devotee. In the Vedantic tradition, this is the state of mumukṣutva (intense desire for liberation) combined with śraddhā (faith) and viveka (discrimination) — all three ignited simultaneously by direct perception of the Divine. The hair standing on end (romāñca or pulaka) is listed in the Bhakti literature as one of the aṣṭa-sātvika-bhāvas — the eight involuntary expressions of the highest devotional experience.
commentary.yogananda: Arjuna's response is the body speaking before the mind has recovered its composure. This is authentic spiritual experience — the organism recognises the Divine before the intellect can categorize and label it. The hair standing on end (hṛṣṭaromā) is a physiological marker of the awakening of spiritual energies — what the ancient texts call 'romāñca' and what modern science might associate with the activation of the parasympathetic nervous system in states of profound awe. Then, instinctively, the palms join and the head bows — the body already knows how to pray; the devotional intelligence of the body is deeper than the rational mind.
commentary.goyandka: This transitional verse is masterfully placed by Vyāsadeva — it captures the exact moment between vision and response, between what is seen and what can be said. Dhanañjaya — Arjuna by his epithet meaning 'winner of wealth' — here wins the greatest wealth of all: direct perception of the Lord's cosmic form. The physical signs (vismayāviṣṭa, hṛṣṭaromā) combined with the devotional posture (praṇamya, kṛtāñjaliḥ) represent the complete integration of outer form and inner experience in the act of worship. The subsequent hymn (v15-31) flows from this state of total surrender — not composed by the rational mind but arising spontaneously from a consciousness that has been overwhelmed by the Real.

verses.sanskrit: पश्यामि देवांस्तव देव देहे सर्वांस्तथा भूतविशेषसङ्घान् | ब्रह्माणमीशं कमलासनस्थम् ऋषींश्च सर्वानुरगांश्च दिव्यान् ||
verses.transliteration: paśyāmi devāṃs tava deva dehe sarvāṃs tathā bhūtaviśeṣasaṅghān | brahmaṇam īśaṃ kamalāsanastham ṛṣīṃś ca sarvān uragāṃś ca divyān ||
verses.translation: I see all the gods in Your body, O God, and all the various hosts of beings; Brahma the Lord, seated on the lotus, all the sages, and the divine serpents.

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna's great hymn begins here — not with theology but with testimony: 'I see.' These are the words of direct experience, not inference or tradition. He sees Brahma on his lotus throne within Krishna's body. This means the creator of the universe is Himself contained within the Supreme. What Brahma creates — time, space, beings, worlds — all of it is held within Krishna. This is the hierarchy of the cosmos revealed in a single vision: the creator is within the Creator, the worshipped is within the Worshipped. Every time we pray, we are somehow touching the being who holds even Brahma in His body.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Arjuna's vision maps precisely onto the Vedantic cosmological scheme: Brahma (the creator-principle, identified with hiraṇyagarbha — the cosmic golden egg), the sages (the ṛṣis who are the cosmic intelligence), and the divine serpents (the primal energies, nāga-śaktis) are all seen within the one Supreme. The Mundaka Upanishad describes Brahman as 'that from which all these beings take birth, by which they are sustained, and into which they dissolve' — Arjuna is experiencing this doctrine not as philosophy but as direct vision. The lotus-seated Brahma within Krishna's body is the specific Vedantic statement that saguṇa Brahman (Krishna) contains and transcends the creative principle (Brahma).
commentary.yogananda: Arjuna is describing the experience that the great clairvoyants and mystics have reported across all traditions — the perception of the inner worlds superimposed upon the physical world. Within the blazing cosmic form, he sees Brahma seated on the lotus: this lotus corresponds in yogic anatomy to the highest lotus of the crown chakra (sahasrāra), where the individual consciousness meets the cosmic. The divine serpents (uragān divyān) are the pranic energies that sustain all life — seen in their true nature as conscious, luminous, and divine. All of creation, properly seen, is a living temple.
commentary.goyandka: Arjuna's vision follows the traditional Purāṇic cosmological hierarchy: at the apex is Brahma, the prajāpati (lord of progeny and creation), seated on the lotus that grew from Viṣṇu's navel. Seeing Brahma within Krishna's body establishes the Vaiṣṇava theological principle that Brahma derives his creative power from Viṣṇu — he is the instrumental cause, while Viṣṇu-Krishna is the ultimate material and efficient cause. The divine serpents (uragān divyān) refer primarily to the great nāgas — Ananta, Vasuki, Takshaka — who are honoured in the Vedic tradition as guardians of cosmic energy and of the waters of life. This verse inaugurates Arjuna's personal testimony which constitutes one of the great hymns in Sanskrit devotional literature.

verses.sanskrit: अनेकबाहूदरवक्त्रनेत्रं पश्यामि त्वां सर्वतोऽनन्तरूपम् | नान्तं न मध्यं न पुनस्तवादिं पश्यामि विश्वेश्वर विश्वरूप ||
verses.transliteration: anekabāhūdaravaktranetram paśyāmi tvāṃ sarvato'nantarūpam | nāntaṃ na madhyaṃ na punas tavādim paśyāmi viśveśvara viśvarūpa ||
verses.translation: I see You on all sides with infinite form, with many arms, bellies, faces and eyes — I see no end, no middle, and no beginning to You, O Lord of the Universe, O Universal Form.

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna is trying to find the boundaries of the Cosmic Form and cannot — no beginning, no middle, no end. This is the experiential encounter with infinity. We use the word 'infinite' casually; Arjuna is actually experiencing it, and it is overwhelming. The repetition of 'na' — no beginning, no middle, no end — is like a mind reaching out in every direction and finding only more God. This is why the mystics say that in God's presence all seeking stops: you cannot find the edges of Something that has no edges. The appropriate response is simply to fall into this boundlessness and rest there.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The three negations — no end (antam), no middle (madhyam), no beginning (ādi) — precisely echo the Vedantic description of Brahman as 'anādi ananta' (beginningless and endless) and the Brihadaranyaka Upanishad's neti-neti method. But here it is not theological negation but experiential: Arjuna looks and cannot find a limit. The two addresses — 'viśveśvara' (Lord of the universe) and 'viśvarūpa' (the Universal Form itself) — point to the same reality from two angles: the Lord who governs the universe (the 'governing' principle) and the Lord who is the universe (the 'cosmic' principle). In Advaita terms, these are Brahman as niyantā (controller) and Brahman as the world itself — both ultimately one.
commentary.yogananda: The vision of the cosmic form that Arjuna is describing — many arms, faces, eyes, infinite on all sides — is not simply a larger human body; it is consciousness itself taking on perceivable attributes for Arjuna's understanding. In the highest superconsciousness, the meditator perceives the one Consciousness as simultaneously everywhere and nowhere, with no spatial boundaries or temporal limits. 'No beginning, no middle, no end' — this is the description of the Eternal Now, the present moment that contains all past and future within itself. To touch even a fragment of this in meditation is to be permanently changed.
commentary.goyandka: The verse's central theological content is carried by the three negations: na antam, na madhyam, na ādi — no end, no middle, no beginning. Traditional Vedāntic commentary (Śrīdhara, Madhusūdana Sarasvatī) notes that these three negations rule out all three types of limitation: spatial (no edge), temporal (no middle implies no timeline), and causal (no beginning). The dual epithet 'viśveśvara viśvarūpa' is especially beautiful — the Lord is simultaneously the ruler of the universe (viśveśvara, trans-cosmic) and the very form of the universe (viśvarūpa, immanent in all form). This is the Gita's most precise expression of the classical theological doctrine: parāpara-brahman, the Supreme who is both beyond and within all things.

verses.sanskrit: किरीटिनं गदिनं चक्रिणं च तेजोराशिं सर्वतो दीप्तिमन्तम् | पश्यामि त्वां दुर्निरीक्ष्यं समन्ताद्दीप्तानलार्कद्युतिमप्रमेयम् ||
verses.transliteration: kirīṭinaṃ gadinaṃ cakriṇaṃ ca tejorāśiṃ sarvato dīptimantam | paśyāmi tvāṃ durnirīkṣyaṃ samantād dīptānalārkadyutim aprameyam ||
verses.translation: I see You with crown, mace and discus — a mass of radiance shining everywhere, blazing on all sides like the light of fire and sun, immeasurable and hard to behold.

word_breakdown.meaning: difficult to look at/hard to behold

commentary.dadaji: The crown, mace and discus are the recognisable symbols of Vishnu — yet here they appear in cosmic proportions, blazing with the light of a thousand suns. 'Durnirīkṣyam' — hard to behold — is physically and spiritually accurate: the divine reality is not easy to look at directly, just as you cannot stare at the sun. The spiritual practice of contemplating God requires what the tradition calls 'antaḥ-cakṣu' — the inner eye — which has been especially opened for Arjuna in this moment. The word 'aprameyam' — immeasurable — is one of the great names of Vishnu in the Sahasranama, reminding us that the beloved form before which we bow is beyond all measurement.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The Vishnu iconography (crown, mace, discus) appearing within the cosmic form establishes that the viśvarūpa is not something other than the personal Lord — it is the same Krishna, the same Vishnu, now revealed in His full cosmic extent. The fire-and-sun simile for the Lord's radiance recalls the Kaṭha Upanishad: 'na tatra sūryo bhāti na candratārakaṃ' — 'There the sun does not shine, nor the moon and stars' — because the Ātman's self-luminosity makes all physical light appear as secondary. 'Aprameyam' — immeasurable, beyond all pramāṇas (means of valid knowledge) — indicates that Brahman cannot be an object of measurement; It is the very ground in which all measurement occurs.
commentary.yogananda: The Sudarshana discus (cakra) of Vishnu in yogic interpretation represents the spinning wheel of time and karma — Vishnu controls time itself. The mace (gadā) represents the power of karma-yoga — the force of right action. The crown (kirīṭa) represents the supreme authority of consciousness over matter. Seeing all of these attributes blazing simultaneously in the cosmic form, Arjuna is perceiving the complete cosmic government — the entire machinery of creation, sustenance, and dissolution held in one hand. 'Durnirīkṣyam' — too brilliant to look at directly — is why all meditation traditions use an intermediary: a name, a form, a mantra — to approach the Infinite gradually.
commentary.goyandka: Arjuna's vision of Krishna bearing the kirīṭa (crown), gadā (mace), and cakra (discus) within the cosmic form is theologically significant — it establishes the identity of the Viśvarūpa with the personal deity Viṣṇu rather than with an abstract universal force. The commentator Madhusūdana Sarasvatī notes that these iconic symbols, familiar to all devotees, ground the overwhelming cosmic vision in the recognisable form of the beloved Lord. 'Tejorāśim' — a mass of radiance — echoes the ancient Vedic Puruṣa Sūkta: 'sahasrārcis' — of a thousand rays. 'Aprameyam' — immeasurable — is one of the thousand names of Viṣṇu in the Viṣṇu Sahasranāma, confirming that what Arjuna sees is none other than the Supreme Puruṣa of the Vedas.

verses.sanskrit: त्वमक्षरं परमं वेदितव्यं त्वमस्य विश्वस्य परं निधानम् | त्वमव्ययः शाश्वतधर्मगोप्ता सनातनस्त्वं पुरुषो मतो मे ||
verses.transliteration: tvam akṣaraṃ paramaṃ veditavyam tvamasya viśvasya paraṃ nidhānam | tvam avyayaḥ śāśvatadharmagoptā sanātanas tvaṃ puruṣo mato me ||
verses.translation: You are the imperishable, the supreme to be known; You are the supreme repository of this universe; You are the eternal guardian of dharma; I consider You to be the eternal Person.

word_breakdown.meaning: to be known/the object of knowledge

commentary.dadaji: In the midst of the overwhelming cosmic vision, Arjuna finds the theological words — imperishable, supreme, repository, eternal guardian of dharma. 'Nidhānam' — the treasury, the ultimate refuge — is one of the most beautiful images: God as the place where everything is safely kept. Every precious thing in the universe — every act of love, every moment of beauty, every sincere prayer — is deposited in this treasury and never lost. 'Śāśvatadharmagoptā' — the eternal guardian of dharma — reassures us that the moral order of the universe is not an accident but is actively maintained by the very Lord we see in this vision.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The four epithets in this verse constitute a compressed Vedantic theology: akṣaram (imperishable — the Katha Upanishad's teaching on the imperishable Ātman), paramam nidhānam (supreme repository — the Mundaka's description of Brahman as the source and resting place of all), avyayaḥ (inexhaustible — the ground that cannot be diminished), and sanātanaḥ puruṣaḥ (the eternal Person — the Puruṣa Sūkta's cosmic Person). 'Veditavyam' — the supreme to be known — parallels the Bhagavad Gita's own statement in 15.15: 'vedaiś ca sarvair aham eva vedyaḥ' — 'By all the Vedas I alone am to be known.' What all scripture is reaching toward is this very being that Arjuna now sees directly.
commentary.yogananda: The universe has a treasury — this is one of the great consolations of spiritual understanding. Nothing true, nothing beautiful, nothing loving is ever lost — it is all deposited in the cosmic consciousness that Arjuna here calls 'paramam nidhānam.' The saints teach that every sincere prayer, every moment of genuine love, every authentic spiritual aspiration is permanently recorded in the divine consciousness. The 'eternal guardian of dharma' is the cosmic moral law — not an external rule but the intrinsic nature of reality itself, maintained by the all-pervading consciousness. When dharma is transgressed, reality itself reacts — not as punishment from above but as the natural consequence of violating the law of one's own being.
commentary.goyandka: Arjuna's theology here converges on several key Upanishadic and Gita teachings simultaneously. 'Akṣaram paramam' echoes Bhagavad Gita 15.16-17 where the imperishable (akṣara) is distinguished from the mutable (kṣara) and the Supreme Person (uttama puruṣa) transcends both. 'Viśvasya paramam nidhānam' — the supreme repository of the universe — is the teaching of the Śvetāśvatara Upanishad: 'yo devānām prabhavaś codbhavaś ca' — 'He who is the origin and emergence of the gods.' 'Śāśvatadharmagoptā' — the eternal upholder of dharma — directly echoes the Gita's most famous promise: 'sambhavāmi yuge yuge' — 'I take birth from age to age' for the protection of dharma. Arjuna's hymn is thus a perfect summary of the Gita's own theology.

verses.sanskrit: अनादिमध्यान्तमनन्तवीर्य- मनन्तबाहुं शशिसूर्यनेत्रम् | पश्यामि त्वां दीप्तहुताशवक्त्रं स्वतेजसा विश्वमिदं तपन्तम् ||
verses.transliteration: anādimadhyāntam anantavīryam anantabāhuṃ śaśisūryanetram | paśyāmi tvāṃ dīptahutāśavaktram sva tejasā viśvam idaṃ tapantam ||
verses.translation: I behold You without beginning, middle or end, of infinite might, of infinite arms — with the moon and sun as Your eyes, the blazing fire as Your mouth — scorching this universe with Your own radiance.

word_breakdown.meaning: with moon and sun as eyes

commentary.dadaji: The moon and sun are God's eyes — one cooling and gentle, one fierce and illuminating. The divine gaze is both of these at once: the compassionate Moon-eye that soothes and the bright Sun-eye that illuminates and reveals. The blazing mouth as fire reminds us of the Vedic image of Agni as the mouth of the gods — when we offer food, our prayers go directly to the Source. 'Scorching the universe with His own radiance' — this is not destructive but purifying: the divine fire burns away impurity and illumines what is real. This is what genuine contact with the Divine does to the soul.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The sun and moon as the eyes of the cosmic being directly echoes the Puruṣa Sūkta: 'cakṣor sūryo ajāyata' — 'From His eye the sun was born.' Here the direction is reversed: the cosmic form sees the universe through the sun and moon, which are thus His organs of perception. The blazing mouth-as-fire connects to the Vedic understanding of vāk (speech/fire) — in the Rig Veda, Agni is the primordial word, the first utterance. 'Sva tejasā viśvam idaṃ tapantam' — scorching the universe by His own radiance — is the teaching of Brahman as the self-luminous source of all heat, light, and energy: the Kaṭha Upanishad's 'tasya bhāsā sarvam idam vibhāti' — 'By His light all this shines.'
commentary.yogananda: The sun-eye and moon-eye of the cosmic form represent the two great cosmic energies: solar (piṅgalā/prāṇa) and lunar (iḍā/apāna) — the masculine and feminine, the activating and the receptive, the knowledge and the devotion. In the human body, the right eye is connected to the sun channel (piṅgalā) and the left to the moon channel (iḍā). The divine being literally sees through these cosmic luminaries — and when the meditator's piṅgalā and iḍā are balanced in deep meditation, they begin to see with something of this divine vision. The fire-mouth consuming the universe is the cosmic pralaya (dissolution) — not destruction but transformation, as fire transforms matter into energy.
commentary.goyandka: This verse elaborates the cosmic physiology of the Viśvarūpa: the sun and moon as the two eyes represent the day-and-night cycle by which the Lord oversees the temporal order of creation (kāla-cakra). The fire-mouth (dīptahutāśavaktra) connects to the Vedic concept of kālāgni — the fire of time that gradually consumes all beings and all epochs. 'Sva tejasā' — by His own self-luminous radiance — is the key Vedantic affirmation: unlike the sun and fire which depend on an external source, Brahman is self-luminous (svayamprakāśa), the light by whose reflection all other lights shine. The three anādi-madhya-anta negations repeat the emphasis of verse 16, reinforcing that the cosmic form transcends all temporal categories.

verses.sanskrit: द्यावापृथिव्योरिदमन्तरं हि व्याप्तं त्वयैकेन दिशश्च सर्वाः | दृष्ट्वाऽद्भुतं रूपमुग्रं तवेदं लोकत्रयं प्रव्यथितं महात्मन् ||
verses.transliteration: dyāvāpṛthivyor idam antaram hi vyāptaṃ tvayaikena diśaś ca sarvāḥ | dṛṣṭvādbhutaṃ rūpam idaṃ tavograṃ lokatrayaṃ pravyathitaṃ mahātman ||
verses.translation: The space between heaven and earth and all the directions — all of this is pervaded by You alone; seeing this wondrous and terrible form of Yours, the three worlds are trembling, O great Soul.

word_breakdown.meaning: the three worlds (earth, heaven, and the netherworld)

commentary.dadaji: Heaven and earth, all directions — the entire space of existence — filled by God alone. This is not metaphor. The devotee who truly feels this cannot move through the world in an ordinary way. Every direction you look, God is already there. Every breath you take, you are breathing the presence of the One who fills all space. The 'trembling of the three worlds' reminds us that the encounter with true infinity is naturally awe-inspiring — even terrifying in its vastness. Yet the devotee addresses this cosmic being as 'mahātman' — great Soul — with love and intimacy. The most terrifying thing in the universe is also the most beloved.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The Isha Upanishad opens: 'Isāvāsyam idam sarvam' — 'all this is pervaded by the Lord.' Arjuna's statement here — 'vyāptaṃ tvayaikena' — is its direct experiential confirmation: pervaded by You alone. The 'antaram' (space between heaven and earth) echoes the Chandogya Upanishad's description of ākāśa (space) as Brahman — 'ākāśo vai brahma' — and here Arjuna discovers that this infinite space is itself filled with the divine presence, leaving no room for a reality separate from God. The three worlds trembling (lokatrayaṃ pravyathitam) is not a description of divine cruelty but of the natural effect of the Infinite encountering the finite: everything relative trembles in the presence of the Absolute.
commentary.yogananda: Space itself is filled with divine consciousness — this is the supreme teaching of this verse. The void between the atoms, the emptiness between the stars — all of it is permeated by the divine presence. This is what the physicist calls 'quantum vacuum' and what the mystic calls 'the divine plenum' — the fullness (pūrṇam) that appears as emptiness to ordinary perception. In deep meditation, this 'fullness of space' becomes directly perceptible: the meditator ceases to experience space as empty and begins to perceive it as vibrating with consciousness. This is the first taste of viśvarūpa-darśana available to the sincere meditator.
commentary.goyandka: The Rig Vedic concept of 'antarikṣa' — the middle space between earth and heaven — is the domain of Vayu (wind) and Indra, the mediating cosmic forces. Here Arjuna declares that this entire intermediate space is pervaded by Krishna alone — not by any subordinate deity but by the Supreme Himself. This establishes the Gita's core ontological claim: the Lord is both transcendent (beyond all worlds) and immanent (filling all space between worlds). 'Mahātman' — O great Soul — is Arjuna's intimate epithet for the cosmic being whose vastness now fills his entire field of perception; it is a title of reverence that combines awe (at the cosmic scale) with love (for the personal Lord), perfectly capturing the mood of the entire Vishvarupa chapter.
